It may have already been stated but here is the answer.  Worms in the video were covered in secretions.  The secretions were sticky and since the worms wiggled through the fine iron particles the sticky secretions picked up the fine iron particles and it was those particles that the magnet picked up.  Since the secretions were sticky they also picked up the worms.  In the video it was shown that the more the magnetic was used to pick up a worm the harder it was to pick up the worm and that was due to the fact that some of the iron particles remained stuck to the magnet.  Wash the secretions off the worms and I bet they are no longer magnetic.  It is not what the worms were eating but where they were traveling that caused them to be picked up by the magnet.

At my last job, we cleaned dirt out of edible beans with a magnetic roller. Somehow, the plain black dirt from the fields had enough magnetism that the magnetic roller would change the angle the dirt fell off the belt. As the beans and dirt fell into a chute, we were able to collect the dirt into a different channel and separate it from the now-clean product. We all called it the magic dirst machine, because it sure seemed like magic in action. We went from having to shake the beans 3, 4, even 5 times, to only having to shake them once, just to get the finer dirt and dust out of them.

So my initial thought was that the worms found out on the asphalt had ingested a large amount of meteorite dust. One of the things I learned in my Astronomy class back in college was that you could go to a storm drain or any small collection of dirt on the road or top of a parking garage, with a magnet, and pick up perfectly spherical, microscopic bits of iron meteorites. Our planet is being showered with them all of the time, but almost everything that goes through our atmosphere is burned up before it hits the surface and turned to dust. For all the iron that comes from space, that heat and the gravity of the Earth, combined, is enough to turn that iron into a sphere. And that's the fun part about finding them with a microscope. From the sample you grab with your magnet, every little perfect sphere you find under that microscope you can tell, for sure, is a meteorite from outer space :)

Hey guys.

Have you talked about this worm "issue" with a professional zoologist? The non magnetic worms seem to look different to me from the magnetic ones - maybe it's got nothing to do with the soil but with the species. I'm not a zoologist or whatsoever - I'm a sport scientist and engineer who knows nothing about animals. However, what I know is that there are such things as magnetosomes - those are small magnetic particles in some living organisms. Migration birds or fish use those magnetosomes to navigate during migration. I can imagine that some worms could be equipped with magnetosomes as well, to navigate underground/ in the dark. Maybe you can go ahead with this small piece of kick-off knowledge and do further experiments or ask a worm specialist ;-) However, I don't know how strong those magnetosomes are and how high the concentration in living organisms is, but I would say that you shouldn't attribute the magnetic effect to the soil at this point of "research" ;-)

Best Wishes from Germany

Iron in soil is always already oxidized, and non magnetic. You need iron have a crystalline structure to be magnetic. Iron crystals form magnetic domains which have all spins aligned. Read a scientific study some years back. Worms become tolerant to metals (even poisonous ones) in time and with exposure. Ultimately they can be used (and probably already are) to handle contaminated ground (like boat yards with poisonous copper forms). After that the ground can be planted with plant fitting for the contamining metal. For example some species of ferns really suck copper out of the ground. Also flax is eager to soak quicksilver from the ground...
Don't know how many cycles are needed to consider the ground uncontaminated though...

My hypothesis: Iron is abundant in the Earth's crust, but it's in the form of various oxides which are variously non-magnetic. Consequently, magnetic worms should only be evident where there are iron filings produced by very recent human activity. Human activity involving alnico alloys or ferrites could create magnetic earthworms in the area for many decades.

Earthworms live on the bacterial scum that covers the fine mineral grains that we call dirt. If magnetic metals are present in the soil in tiny fragments about 0.05mm in diameter or less and there's enough moisture to promote bacterial growth, then you should be able to find magnetic worms.

When I was young my Dad made a tool that my brother and I called the "Worm Chaser". He took a steel rod (about 3feet long) with an insulated handle one end. Then connected the hot (Black wire) from an extension cord and connected the wire a about 2' from the pointed end of the rod. The wrap the wire from cord around the steel rod up toward the handle. Use some black tape to hold the coil of wire in place.

Then plug it in and shove it in the ground. I grew up in the 70's before GFIC breakers were a thing. When you shoved this device into the earth you could feel it vibrating, that how we knew we had the it plugged in correctly ( The 70's was also before polarized plugs ). Then it did not take a minute, earthworms must not like this magnetic field. They would come out on top of the ground. My brother and I would pick up the worms for the fishing trip.

Word of caution - do not put your bare arm against the metal pole when you are grabbing a worm. Don't ask me how I know.

Fun video... Classic SED, but spoiler alert: I don't think the worm was magnetic, I think it was paramagnetic.

I think the "magnetic" worms stuck to magnet for the same reason a grape does, they were full of water from the rain.

Water is a highly polar molecule. The side with the oxygen tends to attract electrons more and is more negative. This leaves the side with the two hydrogen more positive. As a result, every water molecule in a grapes (and worms???) orients itself in a magnetic field.

If you hold the plus side of the magnet near the grape /worm, all the oxygen (negative) sides line up towards the magnet, making that side of the grape / worm more negative. Then the negative becomes attracted to the magnet and viola... Magnetic grapes and worms!

I think the yard worms either weren't as saturated with water or there was too much water in the dirt where the worm was, drowning out the effect.

Science teacher here. :)

At first, given the combined strength of the magnets they were using, I thought it might have been attraction to the water in the worms' bodies. Water is polar, and is attracted to strong magnets. You can see the effect when you hold a very strong magnet very close to the still surface of a bowl of water. The water will actually bulge upward slightly toward the magnets. With EXTREMELY strong magnets, scientists have even levitated a small frog in a specially designed chamber.

But the effect shouldn't have been able to casually lift a worm with the magnets they were using, so I was very happy to see them track down the actual likely reason behind the attraction!

Likely the difference between the worms there, the non magnetic ones in the grass, and the near non existent ones under the steel storage area is toxicity and availability of iron. Around the grinder area, the iron is small, oxidised quickly and is digestible in the food the worm are eating. Out in the grass, the soil is clean, and top soil rarely has native iron in it. Under the steel storage, the iron oxides would be so high as to be toxic to the worms.

I never noticed the worms but I did survey the iron content of quite a bit of the 4 or 5 acres where I grew up by dragging around a magnet. (Mostly like dry beach sand) I found the most near the house, shop, and areas where previous owners burned their garbage. However there was a little everywhere I looked including inside the water capturing parts of bromeliads growing on trees. I'm not sure why it seemed to be everywhere but my pet theories are: Sahara dessert sand blown over the Atlantic--is it red from rust? Iron from wear and tear on machinery blown out the exhaust pipe. Compasses out of microorganisms. And my favorite, micrometeoroids. Since then, somewhere on Youtube I did come across a meteor expert who was collecting them with a magnet off of rooftops and such but you need a microscope to confirm the origin IIRC--almost all of it is manmade. Oh, I also found a lot panning for gold in the creek in the yard in a different state, bag of it near my feet right now. Anyway, I'd guess ferrous worms are widespread but I haven't a clue why the ones under the scrap metal weren't, and why I never found any ferroworms by accident.

As a geologist I can answer the magnetic worm mystery:  Your soil contains Magnetite.  Magnetite is an extremely common mineral which is a ferrimagnetic iron ore.  Try taking the same magnet and moving it over your driveway and soils.  You will see how much magnetite is picked up.  The worms live in and eat the magnetite-rich soil and therefore their digestive tract is magnetic.  Go science!

Worms do have the ability to feel magnetism from studies back in 2015 but the scientist could not determine the exact method. Seeing biological process in bacteria turn silver nitrate into silver nanoparticles (ecoli) firsthand, I wonder if there are processes inside of the worm that reduce iron salts in the soil into nano particles of solid iron that accumulate in the worm and may be the fine detection interface they have for sensing magnetic fields. Would need to cross section ferro magnetic area of the worm , embed in plastic epoxy, slice thin on a tome and then image on a Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope with a high resolution Electron Diffraction Spectrophotometer to see the iron nano particles and verify their composition. We have access to one at the local University and have techniques just developed for using a Dark Field Camera to see the nanometer level resolutions without metal stains. It makes sense that even if the nano particles were there, unless they were grouped together you would not have enough to stick to a magnet, but with some grouping of them due to differences in hydration and fluid flow in the worm you could have concentrations that would stick to a magnet. Just a thought.

Destin, it's been more than 30 years since my high school chemistry class. But I remember that iron has two oxidation forms (ferric and ferrous), but only one of those forms is magnetic. (I think ferric is the less magnetic of the two. But it's more stable and makes up most of the molecules that have iron in them. But, I could be talking out of my butt.) Needless to say, most iron in molecules forms the less magnetic type. It's why magnets don't stick to the ground or your body in the same way it does to the refrigerator door, despite all three containing iron. (Your body has iron in the hemoglobin used by your red blood cells to transport Oxygen around your body.) So, your hypothesis about the pavement worms eating the rusty iron shavings/filings from your work being the source of their magnetism is probably correct because of chemistry, even though both soil and pavement worms have iron in their diets.

I have a curious mind, but I wasn't even surprised about magnetic worms.  Years ago I had a friend, who farmed worms ... mostly sold to bait shops by the pound for fishing, or to garden supply companies to enrich soil.  But I have for years wondered about the cheap protein involved in eating worms.  (Hey ... Snails are a delicacy) To prepare worms for eating one must put them in a peat moss bed for a couple days to a week prior to harvesting for human ingestion.  As worms move through the soil (simplified explanation) by eating the soil taking in nutrients, and pooping out the waste.  Eating a worm picked out of the soil, will cause you to be eating worm + soil.  Eating a worm picked from a diet of peat moss, will give you a worm + peat moss. (probably a more favorable taste than worm in dirt.)  So worms eat soil ... soil has iron content.  Hence some soils, higher in iron content (due to rusty residue from oxidation of metal) means magnetic worms .... simple.
